segments.text: Hello?
Hello, Mr. Green?
Yes.
It's Michelle.
Hi.
How are you, Michelle?
I'm fine.
How are you?
I'm sorry.
Is she there?
Is she there?
Are you ready?
Okay.
Okay, I'll tell you what's going to go on.
The tapes I'm using, they last 30 minutes, and then there'll be a beep, and I'm going to have to get up and turn them over.
And the machine's in another room, so when there's a beep, you'll understand what's going on.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Okay.
Well, let me give you an overview sort of how I'm going to do this.

I'm going to ask you about the Communist Party, what exactly it means, the American Communist Party, as far as does it align itself with Marxism, Leninism, Castroism, Chinese Communism, I don't know, Maoism.
Then I'll ask you about your background, your childhood.
Okay.
your experiences that led you to join.
Yeah.
And then I'll ask you about the trial.
Things happened to you during the trial.
Then I'll ask you questions about your experience as a fugitive and
about the FBI and their harassing your wife and your children and the techniques they used.
And then I'll ask you about some of your experiences in Leavenworth.
And then I'll ask you about, sort of ask you if you could do it over again, how would you do it?
And then ask you about the talk you were going to give here.
Quite a long subject.
Uh-huh.
Is that okay?
Okay.
Okay.
Well, let's begin with the Communist Party.
When you say communists, what exactly do you mean?
What I mean by that is a movement designed in which the wealth and productive powers are inside our own common people.
uh-huh uh-huh
Yes.
Yes.
Yeah.
Yeah.

Well, okay, so, well, do you align yourself with strict Marxist, pure Marxist theory, or do you, I mean, because there's been application of Marx by Lenin and Stalin, and there's... Well, we call ourselves Marxist-Leninists, really, because we believe in the fundamentals of Marxist analysis of Catholic society and the world itself.
uh-huh uh-huh
Yeah.
Mm-hmm.

He believed what happened was that the first country that takes the path of revolution will be that country, not that it necessarily goes developed economically, where the oppression is so great that people revolt.
And the only answer to them is to break away from imperialist domination in another direction.
That was a very fundamental addition to Marxism.
So, in other words, it didn't have to be industrial?
It doesn't have to be as firm as it is.
But Lenin was proven right because old Russia was a very backward country.
Yeah.
And then the revolution switched that.
Take in terms of the other countries in which it occurred, China, Cuba, and so forth, zero, so underdeveloped countries.
While they were the most developed industrial countries in the world,
Yeah.
Well, at one point in your book, you talk about visiting the Soviet Union.
And you say that you had seen that they had advanced considerably.
They had made, I'm not sure what the term is, but you were impressed with the progress they had made since the revolution?
Well, I was there when I referred my book to the period I was there.
In the 30s?
Which was not too long after the revolution.
Yeah.
In 1934, 1932, isn't it?
Yes.
And I described how terrible conditions were.
Yeah.
But at the same time, I was inspired by the kind of a people's movement there was
Do you still hold that?
Well, let's look at it this way.
It was very likely the most underdeveloped country in Europe at the time.
Today, the Soviet Union is the second...
the most important state in the world.
And certainly, it has developed tremendously.
It could not have happened without one, of course.
Furthermore, with all of the backwardness that they still have, lack of things, there are some things that they have that we in the West do not appreciate at all.
For example, there is no illiteracy in the Soviet Union.
That's the way it is.
free education for all, from kindergarten all the way through university, including stipends for those who go to college or university and need public help.
There's also free health care for the very most part, hospital care, which we have a long way from having.
In fact, we're going backwards, cutting, spending on Medicare and other things like that.
We don't have any unemployment in this country.
Also, they have no unemployment.
They have a society based on the principle of full employment.
The last time they had unemployment was in 1930 or 31.
Since then, they've had full employment.
Now, all those things are tremendously important.
Also, take red.
There's no...
A family has to pay more than 10% of its earnings on rent.
The average is really about 5%, 6%.
And that is all established by law that prohibits people being taken advantage of or creating conditions in which people have no means of living and have to be homeless.
There are no homeless in the Soviet Union, as against this very restriction of ours,
Yeah.
But despite the lack of hunger and that everyone does have shelter, don't the Politburo and those up in the social structure, don't they have a lot more than the rest of the people?
I mean, I don't think it's that equal.
Well, I don't know.
First of all, Karl Marx himself put forth the rules for different stages of development.
He said the first stage would be socialism, in which the productive forces of society have not yet reached the point where everybody can have everything on equal basis.
He said the rules for the first period would be following the motto, from each, according to his ability,

to each according to his contribution, meaning that those who produce more, who all give more to society, have a right to have more in order to encourage further activity and giving them incentive for producing and doing more.
He says in the second stage, which he called the communist period, then he says the productive force of society would reach the point where it would be possible to operate on a different model.
The model, he says, from each according to his ability, to each according to his needs.
Because in that second stage...
So we're still caught, or they're still caught in the first stage?
I see.
And when will the second...
When do you predict the second stage coming about?
Yeah.
Because as it is, they have not yet developed an infinity vast size of 30 million.
And this population, they have not developed, come even closest yet to the per capita industrial production in this country.
So they have to catch up with the capitalist West and productivity and things like that.
So certainly they're not going to have the same...
Don't you think that's an unrealistic goal to catch up with?
No, no, no.
Let me ask you this question, though, to make this point.
We are now going through a very complex revolution in science and technology.
In fact, we are having more and more robots replacing robots.
like 4 million robots engaged in the American industry.
By 1990, and that's only four years from now, they expect there will be from 50 to 100,000 robots in the industry.
And the process will continue in an accelerated way.
Today, we are there on the top of an economic cycle.
We're not having a depression right now, but government figures admit that there are 7 to 10 million unemployed in the United States.
Now, what will happen tomorrow as these robots take over and if you enter a department, the number of unemployment is going to continue to grow all the time.
Now, there's one thing.
The day will very likely come when every automobile is built, will be built by robots doing all the manual labor.
But the day will never come when a robot buys an automobile or even a McDonald's hamburger.

In other words, what I'm saying is that the very progress that automation and scientific innovation is producing is going to create a situation in which the less and less workers will be employed, because so long as there's a profit motive in doing that, those who invest in these computers and robots are out to make more profit.
They don't do the damn job when more workers are getting work.
That's true, but...
The change has got to come.
Can I ask you, where do you get your percentages from?
My what?
The percentages you just gave, the statistics, the amount, the robots.
Oh, I got that.
Oh, yes.
And I'll give you the source if you want.
Yeah.
There's a booklet put out by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, the ASLCI.
Uh-huh.
And it's called...
The Future of Work.
Yeah.
And it was put out a year ago.
It discusses precisely this topic.
And it gives official and global statistics in regard to robotization and everything else.
Okay.
So that's the source of it.
Well, so do you...
Does the American Communist Party align itself with the Soviet Communist Party then?
As far as...
Well, do you share their ideologies more so than, say, with Castro or with Chinese?
No, there's no matter of sharing with them more than with the Cubans or with people in Angola or anywhere.
But because we all essentially have the same ideology, often there'll be differences, like in any science.
All scientists may agree on certain principles as time goes on, but they differ in regard to different questions.
And so are the same in regard to the world communist movement.

They agree with one general ideology, but just as Lenin had to make changes, as Marx originally said, because the world had changed, so today we have changes that are taking place that have to change to come.
A country that's underdeveloped has one set of problems than a country that's developed, so that you'll find the applications will differ.
And also, sometimes there are sharp differences, like Chinese under Mao Zedong that developed its own ideology, which now they are .
And Yugoslavs have differences.
the Romanians have differences.
In other words, those who say that the Soviet Union sort of dominates all that, they can see that that's not so because of the very differences that are there.
I see.
And sometimes so sharply that one socialist country will start attacking another.
Yeah.
An ideological question.
Well, are there obvious differences between the United States and other...
And between the U.S. party?
Yeah.
And the... And, say, other countries?
Well... Say the Soviet Union or, say, Q...
Try to apply the principles of Marxism-Leninism to the United States.
Uh-huh.
Well, yes, take in regard to a country like old Russia there.
The revolution came by a violent open field.
Okay.
And in your book, you say that you don't advocate violence at all.
Yes, that's right.
At this point, we're so far off that we don't know under what conditions.
But we believe that it is possible to bring about a very important change in our own violence, and that if violence comes, it's not going to come from the people or from the communists.
The opposition, yeah.
like in Chile or elsewhere, and they will, in the face of the demand of people for change, they're going to try, or they have up to now, most of the time, to try to crush it.
And then the people have got to resist somehow.
No.
So that you put, or take in the different countries that have been oppressed so terribly in the third world, you have guerrilla fighting.
Because
There is no democracy under which to bring about change.
And as John Kennedy said once, he said, if people are not permitted to make a revolution peacefully, they can make it violent.
And that's what's happening there.
But certainly, we would commend, or sharply, anyone who thought to change guerrilla warfare in this country.

And during the 1960s, when you had some of these young people who thought the revolution was around the corner and were trying to imitate what had happened in other countries, the guerrilla warfare, we put the shots down against them.
In fact, I wrote a book called The New Left, Anarchist or Marxist, The New Radicalism, Anarchist or Marxist, which appeared and got considerable circulation in that period where I took issue with it.
I see.
Hmm.
Okay, well, let me ask you questions about your background, then.
So what were your parents?
Were they... Did they... My parents were not born in this country.
Yeah.
Uh-huh.
One was born in...
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
We lived at that time on Jewish.
We lived in what was known as the Jewish ghetto.
Nowadays you don't hear Jewish ghettos.
You get Puerto Rican ghettos, Mexican ghettos, things like that.
Then black ghettos, not in their world.
Were your parents politically involved?
Were they a member of any... Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
He died at 33 years of age.
I was the oldest of three children.
That's why you started to work so young.
And then I had to help out in every way I could.
To help my mother who worked.
Your uncle Isidore, though, was a socialist.
He was a socialist.
By the way, during that period of time, I was younger.
He was a socialist, but he was quiet.
Although he is very well-known, he served, he was sentenced to a 10-year prison term and served a number of years in black, which was an opposition to the war.
Yeah.
And I remember that as a child, as I grew up, I couldn't understand why someone was forced to go to prison.
Mm-hmm.

But in my neighborhood, as I described in the book, there was a socialist center, and workers, sick and dead, benefit from their choral groups, other cultural groups, and also meetings with the Socialist Party and what their youth organization was, the Young People's Socialist Party.
Yeah.
So that...
Yeah.
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
Uh huh.
Uh huh.
Well, you went to one of their meetings, the young... Yeah.
And they were very friendly to you and very inviting.
They invited you to join.
I see.
What's his name, Mr. Harry Gaines?
Gannis.
Gannis, okay.
And he said...
At one point he says something about you don't have to worry your generation is lucky before you reach the age of 25 who will have lived through an American socialist revolution.
When I joined, I was asked whether I couldn't get a meeting with my friends at the locker.
Backward Russia can't be very long before it comes through developed countries of the United States.
My first question comes from one of the young people.
I guess the question we're all very, very interested in hearing the answer.
How long will it take before the revolution comes to the United States?
And he said, well, he said...

Marxism is a science, social science, not dependent on what happens, whether what the ruling class does, also to what extent the mass movement is created, what the character, the leadership of the movement, all that.
But then if you looked at our crestfallen faces, you'd say, well, these kids are lucky.
For anyone who leaves 25 years of age will live through the revolution.
Uh-huh.
Oh, use the term, it's a science.
Use the term science, social science.
Now, why do you use the term science?
Why do I call it a social science?
Yes.
Well, because it's a science that's science.
It analyzes the entire course of human society, ensuring that a man started, a woman started, a human being started, a woman started.
There were no class divisions.
People tended to share.
We have to work in common in order to survive.
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
Nowadays, it's confessed itself.
So what finally happened, however, that was the first and the longest stage of human history, primitive communal society.

Then what happened was, by the development of agriculture, and husbandry, it became, and we developed in a certain, first primitive tools, which enhanced productivity, and what happened was that a surplus was created.
for a ruling class, a group, to separate themselves from the rest of society in terms of income and in terms of certain interests.
So what happened then was that there was the first ruling group, class divisions of society.
And because there were people who were
lived in different areas and often would have overpopulation or would have natural disasters like fires or terrific storms or earthquakes and what have you.
People tended to move elsewhere.
Also it has consequences even in collision with others.
In the early period when one tried
Yeah.
Uh-huh.
Can you...
Can you hold on?
I'm sorry.
It's just beeping and I need to turn it off.
Hold on just one minute.
